video.title: Yellow Taxi Goes Vroom & Phantom Fury | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Indie games on Steam are like mildly hot stupid 
people in Los Angeles, but there&#39;s a couple of

ways they can stand out from the crowd - one, suck 
the right cock, two, have a really eye-catching

name, while sucking the right cock. But going 
down the list of recent additions to the Second

Wind communal Steam account it&#39;s like my eye&#39;s on 
a fucking slip and slide. No shade intended, some

of these games are good, but come on. Children 
of the Sun. Ereban: Shadow Legacy. My mind keeps

wanting to read that as &quot;Raid: Shadow Legends&quot; 
and those fuckers haven&#39;t paid up lately. Eiyuden

Chronicle. Laysara: Spirit Kingdom. There&#39;s 
more bollock sandwiches than at a picnic hosted

by Lorena Bobbit. Thank goodness for Yellow Taxi 
Goes Vroom. Not only is it an eye catching title,

it&#39;s also a sentiment I think we can all get 
behind. Yes, yellow taxis do go vroom. Who among

us could claim to not having gone vroom at one 
time or another. It doesn&#39;t hurt that it&#39;s also

a good game, thank Christ. &#39;Bout time I injected 
some positivity into the year. I&#39;ve been so down

on my review subjects lately I keep knocking over 
the house plants with my hate stiffy. Yellow Taxi

Goes Vroom is a retro-styled 3D platformer 
evoking a sort of N64 era of such things,

structured in the traditional Mario 64 open-ended 
maps collect the Maguffins to unlock new levels

and try not to trip over and blind yourself 
on the huge brightly coloured pixels format,

but does the thing that all modern retro-styled 
games should do, which is to get the look down

and then see how many steroids it can pump 
into this poor little bastard before its

eyeballs explode. So now we don&#39;t have to 
worry about things like loading times or

having to go out and buy the extra memory pack 
on a Christmas afternoon Yellow Taxi Goes Vroom

has the sheer frenetic speed and energy of a 
nervous squirrel getting a contact high from

the floor of a Colombian disco. You play a 
wind up yellow taxi, going vroom naturally,

that is the only vehicle still working after all 
the gasoline in the land becomes possessed or

something thanks to the sinister machinations of 
Alien Mosk, CEO of the Tosla corporation. Which is

about as on the nose as one can get without 
getting bogeys in your hair but after two

seconds of playing Yellow Taxi Goes Vroom the one 
thing one should not expect from it is subtlety.

It&#39;s a madcap explosion of colour and vibrancy 
where everything perpetually jiggles like a

chihuahua doing stay training in 
an abattoir runoff pit. You get

around by zooming - or vrooming if you will - 
through the environments boosting into ramps

to crack off insane jumps to music that sounds 
like it came from a classic Amiga platformer

being hurled down a spiral staircase, and 
it&#39;s fun as hell. Little bit weird, then,

that a very fast paced game about a car doesn&#39;t 
focus on speed challenges. There is some,

but particularly in the back half it&#39;s more 
about exploration and reaching hidden pickups

using all the exotic movement mechanics the 
game doesn&#39;t tell you about at first. Which

I don&#39;t dislike, it lends the basic mechanics an 
easy-to-learn-hard-to-master kind of depth that&#39;s

fun to explore, but I&#39;m also not creaming me jocks 
over the sections where the camera switches to

overhead, &#39;cos the controls abruptly switch to 
a linear 2D system without asking permission and

suddenly we&#39;re playing fucking Pacman and having 
to avoid touching the roaming monsters. Erm,

excuse me, Yellow Taxi Goes Vroom, but the 
established pattern when I run into living

things is that they scream and go flying 
in that hilarious way the Katamari games

always made meat out of. Please ensure your maze 
inhabitants are informed of this going forward.

That aside, it&#39;s absolutely one of those 
innovative mechanics-focused games with

that rare quality of being tightly designed 
while coming across like it doesn&#39;t give a

shit. It certainly doesn&#39;t give much of a shit 
about setting off epileptic seizures. Yeah,

that&#39;s my final word of warning - I know 
standard epilepsy warnings have kinda fallen

into the background of our perceptions like no 
smoking signs and ongoing societal collapse,

but maybe take this one seriously, yeah? 
Maybe skip this game if you are sensitive

to flashing colours, in the way that those 
sensitive to internal hemhorraging should

skip getting buggered by a horse. But while 
staying in the realm of retro-style graphics,

let&#39;s shift gears to a game unlikely to get anyone 
overexcited, Phantom Fury, sequel to Ion Fury, but

having now graduated from the 2D sprites in fake 
3D Build Engine invasion of the very perturbed

cardboard cutouts style we now enter the realms 
of early full 3D. Except with that System Shock

remake style combination of advanced lighting 
effects and really low resolution textures,

which doesn&#39;t look much like how any game from 
the referenced era actually looked, but whatever,

if it means a few texture artists can 
actually see their kids this weekend.

Phantom Fury continues the big vagina flaps 
shooty action but in parallel to the updating

of the graphics, attempts to inject a greater 
depth of storytelling, so wisecracking female

Duke Nukem - Duchess Nuchem if you will - Shelly 
Harrison now has to have a tragic backstory in

which she lost her unit and spouse and arm and 
became a tool of the military industrial complex,

and now her wisecracking one liners read more like 
a severely damaged person showing a therapist on

the doll where she shot her dad. The plot moves 
from cackling mad scientists to corruption within

Shelly&#39;s organisation which means she spends 
the whole game gunning down fellow soldiers

in a way that will no doubt come back to 
haunt her if she ever plans to run for

office. The all but stated goal is to evoke 
Half-Life, but it isn&#39;t much like Half-Life,

the enemies lack for variety and the plot for 
any non-hackneyed element. It more brings to

mind one of the many other forgettable shooters 
from Half-Life&#39;s era, like Soldier of Fortune,

or Sin. And just in case that reference slips 
you by, the main character of Sin literally

shows up for a cameo, to confuse the fuck out of 
all but the twelve people who remember that game.

There&#39;s also a rather adorable play for the 
&quot;immersive sim&quot; label in the way a small child

wearing their dad&#39;s coat is making a play for 
sleeping in the big bed with mummy. How that

manifests is environments loaded with useless 
furniture and flavour trash that can all be

individually picked up and thrown to absolutely 
zero useful effect &#39;cos you&#39;ve got nineteen

fucking guns. There&#39;s also computers through 
which you can access files and deactivate turrets,

except by the time you find them you&#39;ve probably 
already destroyed the turrets because, again,

you&#39;ve got nineteen fucking guns. 
The gun combat&#39;s fine, even fun,

barring the one gun that fires some kind of neon 
electric foam stuff that feels like we ripped it

off a nightclub ceiling, so if you just want to 
shoot orderly queues of faceless mooks all day,

then Phantom Fury provides. If you want a game 
that embodies the purity and greatness of late

90s early 2000s shooters, just replay Half-Life 
I guess. If on the other hand you want a harsh

wake up call so you stop using phrases like 
&quot;purity and greatness,&quot; Phantom Fury will very

effectively remind you that every era also has 
piles of mediocre dross bound for the forgotten

dustbin of history alongside King Edmund II and 
Benito Mussolini&#39;s anger management specialist.
